title: Fall of Jerusalem
shortSummary: Jeremiah 39 recounts the fall of Jerusalem to Nebuchadnezzar and the Babylonian army, the capture and judgment of King Zedekiah, and the destruction of the city. It also highlights God's protection over Jeremiah and Ebedmelech amidst the city's judgment, demonstrating God's sovereignty and faithfulness even in times of national calamity.
timeline: c. 587 BC - Fall of Jerusalem to Babylon

keyCharacters.name: Zedekiah
keyCharacters.description: The last king of Judah who fled during the Babylonian siege but was captured and punished by Nebuchadnezzar.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadrezzar
keyCharacters.description: King of Babylon who led the siege and destruction of Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who remained faithful to God and was protected during Jerusalem’s fall.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuzaradan
keyCharacters.description: Captain of the Babylonian guard who executed the king’s orders, including the captivity of the people and care for Jeremiah.

keyCharacters.name: Ebedmelech
keyCharacters.description: An Ethiopian servant who trusted in God and was promised deliverance during Jerusalem’s destruction.

definitions.definition: A term used for the Babylonian people, especially their military forces.
A Babylonian official or chief officer, often a high-ranking court official.
A Babylonian prince or official mentioned among the king’s princes.
The military officer in charge of the king’s guard and execution of royal commands.
Land given to the poor left in Judah, symbolizing provision and restoration even after judgment.

outline.heading: Babylonian Siege and Capture of Jerusalem
outline.description: Nebuchadrezzar and his army besiege Jerusalem, culminating in the city’s breach and King Zedekiah’s failed escape and capture. This section shows the fulfillment of God’s judgment on Judah for their disobedience.

outline.heading: Judgment on Zedekiah and Destruction of the City
outline.description: Zedekiah’s sons and nobles are executed, his eyes put out, and Jerusalem is burned and its walls broken down, demonstrating the severity of divine judgment.

outline.heading: Captivity and Remnant Left in Judah
outline.description: The Babylonian captain takes captives to Babylon but leaves the poor in the land, showing God’s mercy and provision even amid judgment.

outline.heading: Protection and Release of Jeremiah
outline.description: Jeremiah is specially protected by Babylonian officials and entrusted to Gedaliah, highlighting God’s sovereign care for His prophet.

outline.heading: God’s Promise to Ebedmelech
outline.description: God promises deliverance to Ebedmelech, who trusted in Him, illustrating God’s faithfulness to those who rely on Him even in the midst of judgment.

application: Trust in God’s sovereignty even when circumstances seem dire, as He can protect and provide in times of judgment.
Obedience to God’s word is crucial; ignoring His warnings can lead to severe consequences as seen in Jerusalem’s fall.
Show faith and courage like Ebedmelech, trusting God’s promises even when facing fear and uncertainty.
Pray for God’s mercy and deliverance, remembering that He cares for the faithful and can use even difficult situations for His purposes.

keyVerses.text: But the Chaldeans' army pursued after them, and overtook Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho: and when they had taken him, they brought him up to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon to Riblah in the land of Hamath, where he gave judgment upon him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the capture and judgment of King Zedekiah, fulfilling God’s prophecy about the consequences of his rebellion.

keyVerses.text: But Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard left of the poor of the people, which had nothing, in the land of Judah, and gave them vineyards and fields at the same time.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s mercy in preserving a remnant and providing for the poor even after judgment.

keyVerses.text: But I will deliver thee in that day, saith the LORD: and thou shalt not be given into the hand of the men of whom thou art afraid.
keyVerses.significance: God’s promise of deliverance to Ebedmelech shows His faithfulness to those who trust Him amidst trials.
